newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS-Book-to-bill enlivens hi techs.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS-Book-to-bill enlivens hi techs.

text.p: A stronger-than-expected semiconductor book-to-bill ratio for October enlivened trading in options on high technology stocks, traders said Tuesday.
On the American Stock Exchange, the heaviest trading was in Motorola Inc and Intel Corp options.
Micron Technology and Microsoft Corp topped the actives list on the Pacific Stock Exchange.
Dell Computer Corp was busy on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and International Business Machines Corp and Cisco Systems Inc were active on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.
"It seems like the book-to-bill ratio is having an impact on option volume today," said Michael Schwartz, managing director at Oppenheimer & Co.
"All the exchanges are benefiting from high tech volatility today," he added.

Late Monday, the Semiconductor Industry Association said its book-to-bill ratio, which measures the value of new orders compared with shipments, rose to 1.10 in October from a revised 0.98 in September, marking the first time it has been over 1.0 since December 1995.
Options traders said volatility in high tech stocks -- many got a boost from a rally in the semiconductor group but later slipped -- contributed to heavy action in the options.
"Some of these stocks were all over the place," one trader said.
For instance, semiconductor maker Intel ended down 2-7/8 at 121 after rallying to a new all-time high of 125-1/8 in morning trading. Turnover totalled 12.3 million shares.
Among the options, the November 125 call traded nearly 6,000 contracts. It fell 1-1/16 to 3/4.
